captions.text: So....y'all ready for this.
You have to give Nissan credit.

Despite how powerful and relentless the
GTR may be

the company always seems to find a way
to hone it further

to find more power, sharper, handling, or
better overall performance.

The latest example of their efforts: the
Nismo

and it's the most aggressive GTR we've
seen yet.

Under the hood of the Nismo GTR
it's nothing really groundbreaking at
least versus the original groundbreaking-ness

of the GTR when it first appeared only now
we have 600 horsepower

and 481 pound-feet of torque. Now the
real secret here is that Nissan has
effectively

shifted the power band further to the
high revs with these new turbo
chargers

and a new ignition system that helps
them, you know, figure out the combustion
right. Key points about the GTR

is that it's a midship or premium
midship platform that's what Nissan calls it
they even write it right there
and that means the engine's roughly behind the front axle center

line that's going to help out with
weight distribution

because they mounted the transmission
further in the back that's something we'll look
at later.
Each 3.8 liter twin-turbo V6

is hand assembled by a special Nissan
technician and they get their name

proudly displayed on the very front of
the engine just like you'd expect from
AMG.

If you wanna see where your money
goes

in the GTR Nismo all you have to do is
put it in the air because
man are there a lot of beautiful carbon fibery bits

and vents and all kinds of wonderful
things happening up here. These
fins here are interesting and you might recognize it if you've ever put together a PC
and put a heat sink on these

basically work the same way they're
there to get heat off the exhaust

and there's another pair that we can see
up at the front here.

Now there are vents everywhere they're
feeding the brakes they're feeding all

kind of coolers everywhere. Talking about
breaks

we can get to the wheels and tires. Tires
are special
Dunlop with a hilariously long name it's like SP Sport Maxx DSST 6,000

or something. Wheels in the back are
ten-and-a-half inches wide 20 inches in
diameter
at the front their 10 inches wide 20 inches diameter as well.
That's a lot of front tire up there that's going to help us this thing turn in as aggressively

as it does. Now interesting choice this
titanium exhaust is the first thing you
see

and it's an option and at a price you want
that but I like

is that the haven't bragged about it with
the tail pipes the only way you know
its titanium is
by getting it in the air and looking at it.
Zero to 60 in 2.9 seconds

and the quarter mile in 11.1 seconds
at 125.3
miles an hour.

Braking performance was similar too with
the Nismo taking 97
feet to stop from 60.

But on the figure eight and for the very
first time

the GTR broke into the 22 second range
which is a territory occupied by the
world's best handling
most powerful cars.
A 22-point nine-second lap is the fastest we've ever recorded from a GTR

and its 1.06 lateral G average is the
highest we'd ever seen.
I'll start it out and say that the
GTR Nismo is my new
favorite GTR.
This thing is absolutely insane
its maniacal it's frenetic
it is so much fun.

Now you may not believe that because
when you look at the changes they don't
seem
huge or substantial but this
GTR doesn't drive
like most GTRs.

there's the power of course this thing
is making six horsepower so nissan says

and we're getting them out even though
in california because raising octane
booster

because we have the option six
horsepower that you want to use that

solar power in the high rpm the high
reps
is amazing

but to me it's not just the power it's
the changes

in the chassis what I love most about
this card is the steering and the front
then
it feels sold tight way sharper

way more reactive imprecise then well I
remember from normal GTR sick
considering

how capable those normal GT ours are or
were
Magin how much better this thing is
the drivetrains it's just

I'm the same when you're my power the
car steers

so you can steer with the steering in
you have a lot to grip in the front and

so you can't get around some turns an
amazing rates

but just when you're ready to feedback
that power

and turns even more on see certain
buildings
driving times

for your accelerating maybe at the apex
of a corner maybe slightly before
depending on the turn

and the hardest carries right through at
speeds that

never far more capable through that
specific corner
its it's amazing

yeah this is that Jetstar's have always
been kinda like any other

they're really cool but they just go
about everything wrong because they said

so high and the powers gotta go from the
front to the rear and back to the front
again
and they're heavy and they've got all this and that but like this car makes me
a believer this is, like all right,
okay I'm aboard the GTR trend.
The GTR Nismo is a super low production car way more
money than a regular GTR destroying competitors on the truck.
That's what the Nissan GTR Nismo is good at.
Just more power,
less understeer than some GTRs
I find that as we test GTRs

year by year one understeers more then
the next one understeers less.
This version is right in between.
But the all-wheel-drive and this quick shifting transmission

translate that power and acceleration so
well that for the driver you don't really have a sense of the speed
not until you look at the lap time
and get a sense classes car the motor trade has ever
tested at the Streets of Willow.
Beyond the 600 horsepower the Nismos's upgrades may not seem substantial on
paper

take a look underneath though take a turn
behind the wheel
and you immediately find the effects of Nissan's continued improvements.

GTRs have always been a thrill but
this one takes the experience for them

it's satisfied it's exhilarating the
drive and the fact that we can't find a

streetcar that's faster around three to
Willow

speaks to the GTR's utter capabilities.
Make no mistake
this is the best driving GTR yet.

title: 2015 Nissan GT-R Nismo: The Fastest Yet! – Ignition Ep. 118

comments.author: Tech Cave

comments.text:
It amazes me that none of the other major car manufacturers out there will 
build a car like the GT-R. (7-years into production) Their formula is a not 
a closely guarded military secret. Take a 3.5+ liter V6 (or larger 
displacement) engine, add twin turbochargers, drop in now readily available 
6, 7, or 8 speed dual clutch transmission into an all-wheel drive transfer 
case, in a relatively HEAVY body/frame with a curb weight of nearly 4000 
lbs. Done. They CAN'T replicate that? Really? It's a not a million dollar 
carbon fiber bodied Koenigsegg or a Ferrari with a watered down Formula 1 
engine that revs to 10,000 rpms under the hood. What's the problem? Nissan 
has created a supercar for the masses, and the formula is shockingly 
simple. I can't figure out why their direct competitors are still lagging 
so far behind in their thought process? This car will mop the floor with 
all the other performance cars out there at a price point of 150k or less. 
That includes the new 2015 Corvette Z06, 2014 Mustang GT500, and 2015 
Camaro ZL1 which are still using second-tier supercharger 
technology, instead of the clearly more powerful and efficient top-tier 
turbocharging technology. Nissan has this segment locked up BY DEFAULT.﻿
